**Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis**  
• **Frame 1:** On the far right, there is a green freeway‐style sign reading “To 5 South,” mounted just above a stop sign at the intersecting side street. Although small in this frame, it appears to be oriented so that it would direct traffic to the right. The roadway ahead has “STOP” painted on it, indicating an intersection is immediately ahead.  
• **Frame 2:** The “To 5 South” sign and the stop sign on the right are larger in view, reaffirming that the freeway sign is located on that corner. Nothing suggests a left or straight path leads to I‐5.  
• **Frame 3:** The intersection is clearly a cross street with stop markings in both lanes; the “To 5 South” sign remains positioned on the right corner.  
• **Frame 4:** The black sedan ahead is angled slightly right, consistent with where we see the freeway sign. There is no corresponding signage directing left or straight to any I‐5 on‐ramp.  
• **Frame 5:** From this close‐up view of the intersection, no markings or signage indicate a left or straight path is needed for I‐5 South. The only guidance for “To 5 South” remains on that right corner.  

**Contextual Reasoning**  
All frames show the same “To 5 South” sign located at the right‐hand corner. Standard highway signage practice puts the arrow or sign on the side of the required turn. There is no competing sign for going straight or left to I‐5.  

**Matching to Answer Choices**  
• **A. Left:** No sign or arrow suggests a left turn for I‐5 South.  
• **B. Straight:** There is no indication that continuing straight will enter I‐5, and the “To 5 South” sign is not ahead.  
• **C. Right:** The consistent presence of the “To 5 South” sign on the right side and its orientation strongly indicates a right turn.  
• **D. Insufficient information:** The frames clearly show a “To 5 South” sign at the right intersection, so there is enough information to conclude the correct direction.  

<answer>C</answer>
